courses.name: MATH 133 — Linear Algebra and Geometry]
courses.instructor: Dr. Jeremy Macdonald (coordinator), Dr. Romain Branchereau, Miguel Ayala, Antoine Giard

assessments.title: Assignments released every Friday, due Sunday. Multiple attempts allowed per problem. Each problem has equal weight.  Submission is automatic upon clicking 'submit' for each question.
assessments.description: Assignments released every Friday, due Sunday. Multiple attempts allowed per problem. Each problem has equal weight.  Submission is automatic upon clicking 'submit' for each question.

textbooks: Linear Algebra with Applications by W. K. Nicholson - [ISBN not available]
otherInfo: Tutorials are held weekly and are taught by teaching assistants.  Students are encouraged to ask questions during tutorials and lectures.
Final grade is the higher of two schemes: Scheme 1 (Webwork 15%, Midterm 20%, Final 65%) and Scheme 2 (Webwork 15%, Midterm 0%, Final 85%).
Grading scale: 0-50 F, 50-55 D, 55-60 C, 60-65 C+, 65-70 B, 70-75 B, 75-80 B+, 80-85 A-, 85-100 A. Boundaries may be lowered at instructor's discretion.
Email should be used only for individual matters; use the Ed discussion forum for other questions.
Course information is posted on the myCourses website.
Collaboration on assignments is allowed, but students may not have others solve problems for them.
Contact instructors if the midterm date conflicts with other commitments or illness.
Missed final exams are handled by Service Point.
Resources for math help include office hours (instructors and TAs), tutorials, the Ed discussion forum, the Burnside Math Helpdesk, and SciLearn Peer Collab.
Students can contact instructors regarding life difficulties impacting their studies.
University policies on assessment of student learning, academic integrity, language, accommodations, and a disclaimer regarding unforeseen circumstances are noted in the syllabus.

courses.name: PHYS 101 - “Introductory Physics - Mechanics”]**

assessments.title: Weekly problem sets done online via the Ans system.  Allows multiple attempts; full marks for correct answer regardless of number of attempts.
assessments.description: Weekly problem sets done online via the Ans system.  Allows multiple attempts; full marks for correct answer regardless of number of attempts.

assessments.title: Weekly assignments throughout the semester
assessments.description: Weekly assignments throughout the semester - 15% (lowest dropped)

assessments.title: Weekly problem sets done online via the Ans system.  Allows multiple attempts; full marks for correct answer regardless of number of attempts.
assessments.description: Weekly problem sets done online via the Ans system.  Allows multiple attempts; full marks for correct answer regardless of number of attempts.

officeHours: Tuesdays, 10:00-11:00 am, Rutherford Physics Building room 312
textbooks: *College Physics, 2e* - OpenStax  - Free online textbook.  Donations accepted.
*Physics, Principles with Applications* by Douglas Giancoli, 7th edition (Used copies available at McGill bookstore)
otherInfo: Course uses a flipped classroom approach. Pre-lecture readings are required.
Grading scheme options must be chosen by September 15th.  Default scheme is recommended.
Labs are required and must be passed (55% or higher) to pass the course. There is one virtual and six in-person lab sessions.
Tutorials are held in small groups and focus on problem-solving. Three time slots available (Monday, Tuesday, or Wednesday evenings).
Perusall platform used for pre-lecture reading and discussion; lowest two scores dropped.
Lowest two tutorial scores and lowest assignment score dropped.
A formula sheet will be provided for exams.
Students are expected to spend 10 hours per week on the course.
Information on accessibility resources and academic considerations for missed assessments are provided in the syllabus.
Use of generative AI is discouraged for assignments, but encouraged for understanding course material.  Students are accountable for submitted work.
Students have the right to submit written work in English or French.

courses.name: PHYS 101 - “Introductory Physics - Mechanics”]**

assessments.title: Weekly problem sets using the Ans online platform; multiple attempts allowed; full marks for correct answer regardless of attempts.
assessments.description: Weekly problem sets using the Ans online platform; multiple attempts allowed; full marks for correct answer regardless of attempts.

assessments.title: Weekly problem sets using the Ans online platform; multiple attempts allowed; full marks for correct answer regardless of attempts.
assessments.description: Weekly problem sets using the Ans online platform; multiple attempts allowed; full marks for correct answer regardless of attempts.

textbooks: *College Physics, 2e* - OpenStax (free online textbook) - [ISBN not available]
*Physics, Principles with Applications* by Douglas Giancoli, 7th edition, Prentice Hall (Used copies available at McGill bookstore) - [ISBN not available]
otherInfo: Course uses a flipped classroom approach.
Pre-lecture reading/discussion activities (Perusall) - 7% (default), 7% (Option A) (lowest two dropped).
Weekly tutorials (online small-group problem-solving) - 10% (default), 10% (Option A) (lowest two dropped).
Labs (required to pass the course) - 20%
One virtual lab and 6 in-person lab sessions.
Students must choose one of four grading schemes by September 15th.
Labs must be passed with a minimum of 55% to pass the course.
A formula sheet will be provided for both the midterm and final exams.
Course covers mechanics and waves.
Students should plan on spending 10 hours per week on the course.
Late or missing assessments will receive a score of 0 unless prior arrangements are made with the instructor for documented significant reasons.
Regrades must be requested within 10 days of grades being released.
Use of generative AI is allowed for understanding course material, but not for producing assignments.
Students can submit written work in English or French.

courses.name: ** PHYS 101 - “Introductory Physics - Mechanics”

assessments.title: Weekly problem sets done online via the Ans system.  Allows multiple attempts; full marks if correct.
assessments.description: Weekly problem sets done online via the Ans system.  Allows multiple attempts; full marks if correct.

assessments.title: Weekly problem sets done online via the Ans system. Allows multiple attempts; full marks if correct.
assessments.description: Weekly problem sets done online via the Ans system. Allows multiple attempts; full marks if correct.

assessments.title: December, [date]: Final exam
assessments.description: December, [date]: Final exam - 30% (Default), 35% (Option A), 35% (Option B), 40% (Option C)

textbooks: *Physics, Principles with Applications* by Douglas Giancoli, 7th edition, Prentice Hall (Used copies available at McGill bookstore).
otherInfo: Course uses a flipped classroom approach.  Pre-lecture reading and online discussions are required.

Grading schemes: Default scheme and three options (A, B, C) available until September 15.  Default scheme strongly recommended.  Lowest two scores dropped for Perusall and tutorials; lowest assignment score dropped. Labs are required to pass the course (minimum 55%).

Weekly components include: pre-lecture reading (Perusall), lectures (in Leacock 132, Tu/Th 1:05-2:25 PM), weekly assignments (Ans), weekly tutorials (small groups), and labs (one virtual, six in-person, starting September 16).
Students should plan to spend 10 hours per week on the course.
Email addresses for specific course components: labs101.phys@megill.ca, tutorials101.phys@megill.ca, exams101.phys@mcgill.ca, ans101.phys@mcgill.ca
Use of generative AI: Allowed for understanding course material, not for producing assignments.
Policy on missed assessments: Late or missing assessments receive a 0 unless pre-arranged with instructor for significant and documented reasons.
Policy on regrades: Requests must be made within 10 days of grade release. Contact appropriate email address for each component.
Course taught in English, but students may submit written work in French.
Accessibility resources: https://megill.ca/equity/resources/disability

Late or missed assessments receive a 0 unless prior arrangement is made with instructor for extenuating circumstances.
Regrade requests must be submitted within 10 days of grade release.
Students have the right to submit work in English or French.
Use of generative AI is permitted for understanding course material but not for assignment completion.  Students are accountable for submitted work.
